sn12.15:4.2: Then Venerable Kaccānagotta went up to the Buddha,
sn12.15:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn12.15:4.5: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘right view’.
sn12.15:5.1: “Kaccāna, this world is for the most part dependent on the dual notions of
sn12.15:5.3: But when you truly see the origin of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of non-existence regarding the world.
sn12.15:5.4: And when you truly see the cessation of the world with right understanding, you won’t have the notion of existence regarding the world.
sn12.15:5.5: The world is for the most part shackled to attraction, grasping, and insisting.
sn12.15:5.6: But if—when it comes to this attraction, grasping, mental resolve, insistence, and tendency—you don’t get attracted, grasp, and commit to the notion
sn12.15:5.8: you’ll have no doubt or uncertainty that what arises is just suffering arising, and what ceases is just suffering ceasing. Your knowledge about this is independent of others.
sn12.15:5.9: This is how right view is defined.
sn12.15:6.2: ‘All doesn’t exist’: this is the second extreme.
sn12.15:6.3: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.15:6.5: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn12.15:6.6: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.
sn12.15:6.7: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.
sn12.15:6.9: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
